Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The Genetic Basis of Cytoplasmic Incompatibility
Award.AbstractNarration:
Symbiotic bacteria are extremely widespread in nature and interest in the way that they manipulate animal evolution has risen rapidly in recent years. Discoveries have ranged from bacteria that affect nutrition, immunity, and reproduction to bacteria that cause the splitting of one species into two. An evolutionary enigma surrounds these adaptations - how do bacteria evolve to contribute to these complex animal processes? One of the preeminent bacteria involved in these interactions, Wolbachia pipientis, occurs worldwide in ~40% of all insect species and other invertebrates. Previous work has shown that Wolbachia's ability to alter animal reproduction affects animal populations by spurring the evolution of new insect species, reproductive strategies, and offspring production. Despite these evolutionary outcomes of animal-Wolbachia symbioses, we do not yet know the Wolbachia genes that evolved to control their animal hosts. This study begins the first in-depth analysis of two Wolbachia genes that are likely involved in the symbiosis.

Cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) is Wolbachia's main alteration of host sex ratios. CI drastically decreases fertility of uninfected females in crosses to Wolbachia-infected males and gives infected females a distinct advantage within the population. Preliminary work discovered two Wolbachia genes, with conserved protein and DNA binding domains, putatively involved in CI. To study their interactions, tagged versions of each gene will be expressed in Wolbachia-free Drosophila melanogaster. Immunofluorescent microscopy will then be utilized to determine whether expression of these genes in uninfected males crossed with uninfected females causes explicit CI defects in developing embryos. Next, after dissecting the larval testes, immunoprecipitation of the tagged proteins using commercially available antibodies will be used to isolate any bound host factors. Samples will be prepared for mass spectrometry to determine what host proteins may be bound. Additional samples using chromatin immunoprecipitation, coupled with next generation sequencing, will determine what regions of host DNA are targeted. Finally, candidate Drosophila pathways will be verified for their role in CI through a combination of genetic mutants and RNAi knockdown.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cytoplasmic Incompatibility and Wolbachia

One of the most common and widespread infections in animals is the bacteria named Wolbachia. These bacteria live inside the cells of approximately 40% of the world’s arthropod species including insects, spiders, and mites. Notably in mosquitoes, Wolbachia prevent the transmission of dengue and Zika viruses to humans. Only females transmit Wolbachia to their offspring and in a phenomenon known as cytoplasmic incompatibility, matings between an infected father and uninfected mother typically result in few to no offspring. However, matings between an infected father and mother are compatible and produce normal numbers of offspring. This discrepancy in the number of offspring among the matings gives Wolbachia a big advantage since the females infected with Wolbachia produce more offspring that those females that lack it. Resultantly, cytoplasmic incompatibility, or CI, is in the vanguard of vector control strategies to spread Wolbachia into mosquito populations that in turn curb dengue and Zika virus transmission.

Despite over 40 years of research on CI and Wolbachia, the genes that enable Wolbachia to cause CI remained a mystery. We uncovered four key results. First, a set of unbiased, comparative sequence analyses revealed two adjacent genes in the WO virus region of Wolbachia’s genome that may cause CI. Second, transgenic expression of these genes, cifA and cifB, in the genomes of uninfected Drosophila flies recapitulated the reduction in offspring number and chromosome defects associated with CI. Third, transgenic expression of cifA and cifB in infected flies enhanced Wolbachia’s natural ability to cause CI. Fourth and importantly, matings between fathers expressing the transgene-induced CI and Wolbachia-infected mothers were compatible, as expected.  Finally, these genes coevolved and are upregulated in infected fathers where they initiate CI.

These results show, for the first time, that the genetic basis of CI is relatively simple. The cifA and cifB genes are, strictly speaking, viral inhabitants of Wolbachia’s genome and coevolved to cause CI.  The discovery pioneers futures genetic and mechanistic studies, including ones that evaluate their efficacy and delivery as a as a tool to control diverse diseases transmitted by mosquitoes.
